title: Faith and Righteousness
shortSummary: Romans Chapter 4 explores the foundational biblical truth that righteousness is credited through faith, not works, using Abraham as the prime example. Paul emphasizes that justification comes by faith in God’s promises, highlighting the grace that undergirds salvation for all believers, both Jews and Gentiles.
timeline: c. AD 57 - Paul's Epistle to the Romans during his missionary journeys

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch of Israel, used as the primary example of justification by faith apart from works or the law.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The king and psalmist who is quoted to affirm the blessedness of forgiveness and righteousness imputed without works.

definitions.definition: Declared righteous before God, not by works but through faith in His promises.
To credit or attribute something to someone’s account, especially righteousness credited to faith.
A physical sign of the covenant given to Abraham, symbolizing belonging to God’s people, but not the basis of righteousness.
Trust and belief in God’s promises, which results in righteousness being credited to the believer.

outline.heading: Abraham Justified by Faith, Not Works
outline.description: Paul begins by asking what Abraham discovered regarding justification, concluding that Abraham was justified by faith, not by works, setting the foundation for the doctrine of grace.

outline.heading: Righteousness Apart from Works Confirmed by David
outline.description: Paul cites David’s words from the Psalms to reinforce that blessedness comes from forgiveness and righteousness imputed apart from works.

outline.heading: Faith Credited Before Circumcision
outline.description: Paul explains that Abraham’s faith was credited as righteousness before he was circumcised, making him the father of all who believe, both circumcised and uncircumcised.

outline.heading: Promise Received Through Faith, Not Law
outline.description: The promise to Abraham and his seed was through faith, not law, emphasizing that faith ensures the promise by grace and that Abraham is the father of all believers.

outline.heading: Abraham’s Faith Exemplified
outline.description: Paul highlights Abraham’s unwavering faith in God’s promise despite natural impossibilities, demonstrating the power of faith to overcome doubt.

outline.heading: Faith’s Blessing for Believers Today
outline.description: The chapter concludes by applying Abraham’s example to believers, showing that righteousness is credited to us when we believe in God who raised Jesus from the dead, who was delivered for our sins and raised for our justification.

application: Trust in God’s promises rather than relying on personal efforts or religious rituals for righteousness.
Embrace faith as the means by which God credits righteousness, leading to peace and assurance before Him.
Recognize that God’s grace extends to all who believe, regardless of background or works.
Strengthen your faith by focusing on God’s power to fulfill His promises, even in seemingly impossible situations.

keyVerses.text: For what saith the scripture? Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the core biblical principle that faith, not works, is the basis for being declared righteous before God.

keyVerses.text: But to him that worketh not, but believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly, his faith is counted for righteousness.
keyVerses.significance: It clearly states that justification is credited to those who believe, emphasizing God’s grace toward the ungodly.

keyVerses.text: Therefore it is of faith, that it might be by grace; to the end the promise might be sure to all the seed; not to that only which is of the law, but to that also which is of the faith of Abraham; who is the father of us all,
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights that the promise of salvation is guaranteed by faith and grace, extending to all believers, not just those under the law.

keyVerses.text: Who was delivered for our offences, and was raised again for our justification.
keyVerses.significance: It connects Jesus’ death and resurrection directly to our justification, affirming the foundation of Christian faith.
